I have been going to this place for years.  It has great service, good breakfast food and the beat prices you will find anywhere.

This is the perfect place to go on a weekend when you don't feel like cooking breakfast. The staff is always so nice, and the food is actually really good and fresh.  My son loves to go because of the classic car display case they have.  I have never been disappointed by this place. 

Ok i am going to say this, but i mean it 100% in a complementary manor.  You know when you see an IHOP or Denny s commercial and you think to yourself "WOW that look SOOOO GOOD!"  Then you make the mistake of going and what you get looks nothing like the commercial and tastes less then mediocre.  Well this place serves breakfast that looks like TV commercials and adds.

The corned beef hash is fresh corned beef and not canned...that is always a relief for me because i consider myself a corned beed hash connoisseur.  

The menu is very traditional so don't expect anything unusual here.  Traditional farmer breakfast, nothing fancy here.  Good old fashioned breakfast.
great service.  good food.  totally "American Classic" breakfast.  No online menu, so I took pictures, and will post if I can figure it out.  Oh, and this is a cash only place.
Great food at a great price.  Service has been great everytime we've been there.  One of the few remaining places that doesn't take credit cards.

Great little restaurant! The food had that old fashioned dinner feel to it, and it was well executed in that style. It is a little small inside so it can get loud, but it gets a hearty thumbs up from me.
This is a great hometown diner. Very small townish. The food was great and the staff was very friendly.

I love this place. Very good diner food, friendly staff....who remember what the regulars names and what they like! I love the small town, truly family feel of this place. I look forward to doing my crossword puzzle, saying hello to familiar faces and enjoying the homemade soup of the day or a hearty breakfast. You won't be disappointed.

Been going to this place for years.  Great Food!!  Great Value!!  Great Service!!  I see there have been comments  about not accepting credit but come on people, this is how they keep their prices so good so you can't have your cake and eat it too.  Whatever they do, they do it right.

This is your Classic American Diner! And the food is really, really quite good.  The other breakfast places and diners can't compare.

I struggled whether to give it 4 or 5 stars because it's small inside, but we usually always get a table right away.  Weekends you can about 15min.  Not downgrade worthy in my mind.  And Two: Cash Only!  Consider yourself warned.  The food is worth it.

PS.  I think they should charge more.  Really I do.
Great hometown type of restaurant. Comfort American food menu. Big servings and fast. Quaint and cozy feel. Friendly waitresses. Cash only.

The food is really good, and it is a friendly atmosphere. It seems like a diner where you could become a regular. I have never had bad service. The only two downfalls I see is that it is kind of small (so limited seating), and that it is cash or check only.

There are two things that stand out about this restaurant. 1.) The service is so friendly and fast, you think your on another planet. 2.) The food can be explained in one word, Homestyle. This is the type of food that reminds you of home. I can't say enough about this place, other than I wish it was closer to where I live!!

The waitress encouraged me to build my own skillet when I just couldn't decide from the many tasty options. Hash browns come out crispy when ordered that way, piping hot food, perfectly over easy eggs, and my boyfriend loved his chorizo omelette with jalapeÃ±os.  Omelette was just right; not too fluffy. Can't wait to go back. The entire staff was great.

Good 'home cooked' food, friendly fast service and big portions. When the bf and I have time for a sit-down breakfast on the weekends we head here. Sometimes it's crowded but the wait is never long. The food is tasty if not particularly healthy and if you clean your plate while you're there you'll  be too full. The staff tends to be pretty steady which is always a good sign. Two thumbs up on this one, go here for a good price on a good meal and keep a local business open so we don't have to get our grub from Red Robin!
Great place for breakfast in downtown Oswego. Good food and great prices. Packed on the weekend.

Corned beef cut chunky or sliced thin...always a delima! 

Taking a seat at the bar I noticed my neighbor and his dark rye bread, mmm corned beef. As I write I get a message that says "we are spoiled." Eating good food can spoil you and I know a chef!

I am enjoying quite a good sandwhich, the fish fry just got served behind me which throws a curve, but tonight's thinly sliced sandwich on DARK RYE is tasty.

Been here before just for drinks, tonight the sandwich hit the spot, local friendly place.
Really good good food!! And lots of it! Great prices. Quick and friendly service. Southwest turkey panini...kids mac and cheese....and pulled pork sandwhich...all came with soups and fries!

Every time I've been here the food has just been ok never anything out of this world.  There's always a weird funky smell in the place kind of like old grease.  I've always heard never to order specials in restaurants because that's usually old food the kitchen staff needs to use up.  They were right.  I ordered the sirloin steak special medium rare and it came out well done.  The steak also tasted funky like it was old and starting to spoil.  Frozen vegetables....not impressed with that......overdone to complete mush.  I said I didn't want any butter and sour cream on my potato and it came out with both.  My wife also asked for no pickles on her sandwich and it came with pickles.  I wanted soup of the day to go and the waitress forgot to give it to me.  And lastly it took forever to get our bill and it was slow as hell that night.  I will not be returning.  It's so frustrating spending hard earned dollars on food that tastes like garbage.  I could have cooked a better steak dinner at home for half the price.  This place deserves to go out of business.

Poor poor bar service! Only three of us at the bar. Came in , she got me a beer, great. Then proceeded to sit on her phone talk to coworkers and get hugs from another patron. NEVER came back to offer me another drink or food. In over 20 minutes. I sat there with my empty glass on the edge of the bar. Probably worst service I have ever experienced.
Yum! It doesn't look like much from the outside, but the food is fantastic! Just had lunch and the sandwiches all come with a sizable cup of delicious soup.

For this type of spot, I don't think it can get much better. Hubby had the prime rib special and the ladies cut was HUGE! Served with soup or salad, he spent $1 more for the French onion soup and it was a large bowl with loads of cheese. I had the fried shrimp dinner and there were 8 butterflied shrimp with a light crispy breading, quite the large serving with fresh steamed carrots and broccoli and a baked potato that was baked to perfection!  I am going back one of these Mondays for a half price burger, advertised in the menu as 12 OZ!!! I thought the prices were very fair, even low for the portion sizes. Lots of salads too that I will have to try...

I had hesitated going here, because when it was Tommy O's it was nasty. But a friend went and said the food was good, and I am glad I listened. We will put it on our "don't feel like cooking go-to list"...

I have been here several times now over the years. One of my favorite places in the area. Food is good and staff is always warm and friendly. Especially great for sports games. Definitely  recommend checking out the new patio addition!
Close. Convenient.   Never busy.  Why?  Other local places packed from their very first day.  Wake up, management.   Bathrooms dirty.   Management should lead by example .  What's your problem?

Murky at best... Sat at the bar on a friday with a buddy and had a few good beers. All was good until a kid started cleaning a cooler directly in front of us. Now that both of us are management in the industry, we sit back and watch the brown slim coming off of the one towel he was using. The manager cane over and talked to him and told him not to stop until he was finished.... Maybe doing this before the day starts would help.
The bartender came over and asked if we wanted food and after seeing what was taking place in front of us we said know. Her response was "good".

I believe with better management this place could be better.

I usually like the food here, but I recently bought a $28 Medium Porterhouse steak thinking I'd get the same quality. It's the first steak I've had here and the staff are very good at taking my order and serving me. But, my steak was dry, nearly well-done and seemingly cooked on an unclean grill. The side portions were generous and I'm usually full halfway through the sides. Edible that night at best. I ordered on a night that was only somewhat busy out of consideration for the great staff, but that kind of cooking is unacceptable.

I'm not sure I can think of a more nonsensical and inappropriate example of restaurant management than what I encountered here.

As a part of the weekly trivia event, "tasty prizes" (shots) are awarded to teams who guess certain answers correctly. I can't drink alcohol, and each week the trivia host instructs the teams that if any of the prizes are not wanted, we can bring them to his table to share with his team. We gave the unwanted shots to the host, and were approached by a waitress a few minutes later who threatened to *ban us from the bar* if we were to ever do this again. Um... what?

We asked if she was aware that we were told to do this by their host, and she said that she was. "Management, however, doesn't feel comfortable approaching the host and telling him he can't do this, so they're just telling the customers. The trivia staff drink for free and are paid to be here, so they don't need your shots."

The manager doesn't feel comfortable talking to his own contractor? So he instead wants to threaten to ban the customers? Brilliant. And if the staff drink for free, what in the world does it matter if they have my shot or order their own?

No problem. Weekly customers for years, and we won't be back to Oak Street. Though I do thank the bar for giving me a little "street cred" -- I've never been threatened to be banned from a bar! :)  Ridiculous.
The food is excellent. Service is great. Try the buffalo shrimp you won't be disappointed. I will be coming back.

I love oak street because the location is less then 7 mins from me. Also right next door to two of my good friends houses!!! We love to eat and drink there. It's very homey and tge stuff is nice. Good food especially their french onion soup. Love!

We go to Oak Street ever Monday night for 1/2 price burgers. 
Best burgers around... especially when you get them 1/2 off!
This is our go to restaurant in town since it's walking distance from our house. Everything we've had at Oak Street is tasty and reasonably priced. We've also had several parties in the private room and the service is always fantastic!

i was looking around for a place to get something to eat and to do Karaoke. I found a review that told me this place had Karaoke on Thursday. I thought I would be smart and check. Many places cancel Karaoke and it still shows on the web sites. I called and asked about Karaoke. I was told that it would start at 9 PM. I showed up early and ordered my food. I asked again if Karaoke was tonight since there was no one setting up. I was once again reassured that it was Karaoke night. I ate and someone finally came in around 10 mins before 9 and started to set up. At 9:30 I was told by the bartender that it would start any minute. After 9:45 I paid my check and left. I noticed that the manager was playing slot machines so I didn't interrupt him and was angry the whole way home. I called and asked for the manager, I was told "Who is this and why do you want the manager" I found that very poor. I waited a few minutes,(my guess is for him to finish his game) told him my story and told me that the person that i spoke with was misinformed. I could have asked which one since i spoke to someone earlier and to my bartender that was there tonight. This is really sad because he clearly doesn't realize that no mater who was misinformed it is his fault for not properly educating his staff. I live 2 miles away and love to do Karaoke. I will never be back. Restaurant owners try things like Karaoke to increase their business and are surprised when it doesn't work. But the problem isn't Karaoke or the band, or $5 martini night that they try. it is simple, give good service, provide quality food, and do what you say you are going to do. it is service that brings people back. This place has no clue as to good service. 

I cant believe the manager didnt say please come back sometime, or tell me that they will do better. He just blamed his staff. What a loser!

Can't beat 1/2 price burgers on Monday! Food is always good! When you're there ask for Jen the bartender--she's the best! Always a fun time when we go there. Chicago games are always on the big screens!

I think I need to explain that this review is as much a comparison to the previous tenants of this location as it about this restaurant itself.  Not that it would take much, but what a huge improvement over Tommie O's.  Once we arrived and the front of the building was devoid of the street pharmacists that plagued Tommie O's, I knew Oak St. was already moving in the right direction. 

Casual, simple and bright are the first things that popped into my head.  The 'stone' that now dominates the entire back wall looked nice and all the partitions and other crap was gutter to create a large open dining space separated by an open wall with a large bar area next to it. We arrived around 10 p.m. for a late dinner and joined a couple of other tables dining and a fairly large crowd at the bar. I would say the vast majority of folks were 20 -30's and were dressed as if Oak St. was pregame for some other late night spots.  Pleasantly surprised to find a young-ish crowd in North Aurora at somewhere not named The Turf Room. 

Good selection of beer and wines, I got a personal favorite Fat Tire and my companion got a Ecco Pinot Grigio.  We started with the buffalo shrimp appetizer which was a great start to the meal.  We followed that with her getting the french dip and I got the BBQ pulled pork.  Not only did we enjoy both our sandwiches but both meals came with a salad.  Apps, salad, sandwiches and two drinks each for under $40, wow. 

Our server was dead on all night.  The app, salads, entrees and drinks were like planes at O'hare coming and going with perfect timing.  He was excellent and only made the experience that much more impressive.  He got well over 20%. 

Next time I will try a pricier entree and further explore their draft beers.  Great addition to the neighborhood.
Food was just ok. Been there 3 times. Every time i have noticed the bartenders look unhappy. No smiles and upbeat personalities. Hope this changes

We went here during the soft opening, they have since had their grand opening. I must say starting with the over all appearance they gutted most of the restaurant and have made it a very beautiful interior. 

I ordered the chopped steak dinner, it was great. My better half ordered the broasted chicken and it was far superior to the broasted chicken that used to be served when this location was Tommy O's!!! We will be going back for sure!!!! I wish Oak Street Restaurant and Bar the best in their new home!!!!

I haven't had a bad experience here.  Friendly staff, good food, and laid back atmosphere.  Thursday night is karaoke night, which I've attended several times and had a lot of fun.  It's especially entertaining when the locals take the mic and freestyle rap.
We're in Aurora once a week and decided to try this place, I would definitely recommend it the at atmosphere and service was great. We definitely we return.
The place is changed.    They go threw bartenders like every 3 months ! NOT consisting  not very fun like it use to be

I`m a big fan of their cherry coke; it's unlimited refills, they add their own cherry flavor, and it's only $2. However, the rest of the menu seems a bit pricey, but that's only because they give you so much food. Every item on the menu seems to come with  soup (my feverite is the french onion) and unlimited freshly baked bread. This place looks so much better than when it was Tommy O's. Wait staff has been friendly. I am always over stuffed when I leave.
Restaurant is remodeled and beautiful, drinks are food are a bit overpriced and food is just average.

We typically come here a few times during the summer, before we visit the DG Friday night car show. The food and service has been consistently good. I usually get the turkey burger which has a delicious bun and flavorful pesto. This time I opted for the sweet potato fries, which didn't disappoint. However, I often get the truffle fries which are delicious and a definite step up from plain-ole fries. I realize that they are a brewing company, so they promote their own brews. But, I'd like to see a listing of other brews offered. 

Finally, as a mom of two toddlers, I absolutely love their kids dinners. Not only do they offer a variety of meals, but they come with a little TOY!!! This is always a treat for the kids, is appreciated by me, and keeps them entertained during dinner.

I'm updating my review for a couple of reasons... the manager was kind enough to reach out to me via private message about the last review and made an offer for a return visit. It really left a good impression, so I agreed to leave an updated review after giving Emmett's one more try.

A friend and I went around 8pm on Friday evening. There were no sports games on at all (I thought this may affect the bar population), but the place was still packed 100% with people waiting in the over-crowded lobby area.  We waited about 20 minutes near the bar area as we saw some people were getting ready to head out and we preferred to sit on that side. A guy with his 4 friends in tow blasted right past us, looking for a seat.  When he saw it was fully packed, he proceeded to stand right in front of us.  When my friend finally got irritated and told him we were waiting, he gave us a crappy look (it's a "first come/first serve" seating arrangement).  He basically ignored her and kept walking around looking.  She elected to ask for the manager, as she felt that was rude and I can't say I disagree with that. She mentioned we were there with a credit, as we already had one bad experience.  He assured her this experience would be better.  We found a table, but pretty much had to run over and sit down before the other guy got there... so thanks but no thanks to the manager for his help (or lack thereof).  The guy even made a comment "there's only TWO of you and MORE of us" as we walked by.  Classy.  We got there at least a half hour before they did - but apparently that did not matter.

I like the atmosphere in the bar, it was a fun vibe and not so crowded that you feel closed in on top of one another.  The tables and chairs are the high top kind and wooden with higher backs on them. There were multiple TVs with different things on, but the music was on the speakers and it was a really nice variety of 80s, rap, a few older songs, etc.

Our waitress was nice.  I had the reuben sandwich, which was pretty darn good.  My friend had a turkey sandwich, it had bacon on it.  She liked it as well.  Also, the food was out in minutes.  We both went with the Octoberfest beer which was extremely good - I would absolutely recommend it.  However, once again... none of the beers were explained to us... and none of the specials offered.  I've been to many breweries in my lifetime and I always have heard the specials or at least a recommendation or something.  We were given a menu and asked what we wanted. 

The service was good.  The atmosphere was not too loud, but not too quiet either.  We were offered a dessert menu this time, we had no idea it existed as the previous waiter didn't mention it.  They had a nice variety of creme brulee, ice cream, snickers pie, etc.  As badly as I wanted to get something, I was too full off just 1/2 of the sandwich and fries.

Overall, it was a decent experience... but once again... I wasn't so blown away that I'm dying to go back.  In fact, I probably won't, to be honest.  The beer is good, the food is decent, but I still maintain that there are cheaper places with more convenient parking and at least 2 seats available that late at night.  Finally, if the manager had come back to check on us (knowing we were there specifically because we were given a credit to return once more AND were being bulldozed by a rude man and his posse), it probably would have made a giant difference to me.  I am so/so on this place.  Still just don't see what the hype is about.

Came here with my family for a little hangover lunch. The nachos were pretty good. Wish they would've added more cheese to it. My ribs were okay. I didn't like the sides - vegetables and a baked potato. Boyfriend ordered a jalapeÃ±o burger, he thought it wasn't anything special. I'd come here again, maybe something different will fancy my liking.

They could also clean their tables a little more. Half the booths and tables were kind of dirty. Don't know if they were understaffed that day or what.

I have dined here before which, is why when my friends wanted a recommendation for dinner, I suggested Emmett's. I told the host that we had a dog and he said that we could sit on the patio. Shortly after reviewing the menus we were asked to leave because dogs were not allowed on the patio. Now, this dog is the most well behaved, quiet dog you would ever meet. Certainly did not cause any problems. Many of the people sitting around us loved the dog. 

We walked down the street to another bar and our dog was welcomed with a bowl of water and treats. I have lived in Downers Grove my whole life and anyone who has been there would agree, this is a family oriented, smaller town with a very warm welcoming culture. Dogs are family and to be asked to leave because of him is very disappointing. Shame on management for this antiquated rule in a family oriented culture.
Very good brewery with decent food as well. Staff is friendly and the atmosphere is relaxed .

The beer was good however the food not so much.  We started with potato skins, the ends of the potatoes were hard. My boyfriend ordered the fish and chips $17, he got two very small pieces and the coleslaw tasted like it was old. The bartender gave us very little attention and didn't tell us anything about the beers (this was our first time there) I ordered the Brew-something chicken sandwich it was okay but I've had better. I was very disappointed I thought this would be our new spot.

I went here for the first time last night (Tuesday) for dinner and drinks and am confused by the few negative reviews that I read! My boyfriend and I decided to sit at the bar instead of in the dining room so we could better see their different drink options. The bartender, Elvin, attended to us immediately and took the effort to ask us what we normally like to drink so that he could make recommendations. We were lucky to have stopped in on such a good night for specials...all of their draft beers were only $3! We tried their stout, red ale, and pale ale...all were delicious! I also ordered their classic cosmopolitan, which was arguably one of the best I've ever had.

Although we weren't incredibly hungry, we did share a few dishes. First, we had the walleye bites appetizer. The batter on the fish was light, flaky, and perfectly seasoned. They came with a sriracha aioli, which was incredible. After that, we split the brewer's chicken sandwich with a side of their house-made blue cheese & bacon potato chips. The chicken was juicy and thinly sliced. It was topped with bacon, Swiss cheese, and a tasty pale ale mustard sauce and served on a pretzel bun (can't go wrong there). As much as I loved the sandwich, I think I loved the chips even more! They are served with a side of this magical creamy horseradish dip that I would literally put on every meal if I had access to a jar of it. 

To anyone debating about whether or not to try this place...go! I refuse to believe that the negative reviews are legitimate. If possible, go on a Tuesday evening when Elvin is bartending because he is the very best!

The parking situation seems dire but there is a lot across the street.  This place is large and has two separate spots; one more of a traditional dining room and one more like a pub.  I think it's a good idea as one side is more family oriented and the other is a friendly, fun atmosphere.  The service was pretty good, not spectacular.  It was also quite warm in there.  They had a wing special that was $0.50 with a dozen minimum.  They were good.  I especially liked the jerk sauce.  The spinach artichoke dip was good but nothing special.  The pretzels were solid as well.  Overall, decent bar food, cool ambiance and good service.

This place COULD be awesome if they had top-notch Management and staff...but, unfortunately, it seems like there's consistently a problem with service there.

As for the beer and food, I'd rank their Victory Pale Ale in my top 5 list for great Chicago area beers...and their food can be really good when the cooks don't screw up the order or the waitress doesn't forget about the food you and your date ordered 30 minutes earlier.

I will continue to stop in from time to time for a cold pint, but I probably won't bother trying to order food. :(

I have now been here twice & each time I like this place more & more. They have a big variety of food to pick from, sometimes I hardly know what to order. The best part though is the atmosphere. It was nicely decorated, almost as which you feel like you're at a fancy dining place. Their little brewery gives it character. The food is very yummy & not even that expensive! I will definitely try to return in the future.

Solid brew pub out in the western burbs, I got the chicken sandwich and a cup of the cheddar ale soup which was really good, and i had never had an ale soup before so I'd recommend that. I also got a flight of their beers, all were good, especially the english pale ale and the stout. I got a 6 pack to go, which was a bit pricey but still good that they offered it. Good to watch sports games at and get good food and craft beer in the process

While I have no complaints about the food, the service in the bar is pretty much non-existent.  It's a pretty quiet Saturday afternoon so there is no reason for me to have sat for almost 10 minutes before being asked what I'd like to order.  Good food!

It was a bright Saturday hot afternoon, so I decided to have sip of beer over here.
And here was an unexpected great experience waiting for me in Emmett.
As I went in it was mostly empty with few people in dining and bar area.
I was received nicely at reception and seated comfortably in dine-in area.
Patrick was our the server on that day and he suggested to try German Kolsch as a cooler and refreshing beer for the hot afternoon.
As this was my first experience in a brewery so I ordered a beer paddler which is a combination of 5 beers (Munich Light German Lager, 1 AM English Ale, Emmett's Pale Ale, Emmett's Red Ale, Porters and Stouts). I personally loved German Lager which was crisp and refreshing.
For food I ordered Three Wings Sampler(one of each buffalo, Jamaican Jerk and red ale BBQ) and Emmett's Nachos with Emmett's Club Sandwich.
Food was really good, but the service made it best experience.
I have read many average as well as bad reviews of this place, but as far as my experience it was excellent and I would soon be there again to try out more items on menu.

My friend and I were just walking around Downtown DG and looking for a place to grab a bite and a drink. This place caught our eye. We asked for a table for two but it was about a 10-15 minutes wait so we decided to get a couple of beers while we waited. Emmett has a brewing factory next to its bar and you can see the big beer silos from the bar area. My friend and I enjoyed our beers and soon enough, our table was ready so we moved to the restaurant side for the rest of the night.

The bar is pretty spacious with lots of small tables with stools for you to sit and I believe you can order food here, too.

We did have an option to keep the tab open and pay later when we got our table on the restaurant side but we decided to just close the bar tab before migrating.

After hearing so much about Emmett's (one of my coworkers is seriously obsessed), we decided to finally head out and meet up with friends there one Saturday night. I was pretty psyched, since A.) I love a good pub burger, and B.) my husband's name is Emmett, so I was hoping to score some Emmett swag.

We arrived to the sound of live music and a pretty lively scene. Though there appeared to be quite a few parties going on in the private areas, we didn't have to wait too long for a table to become available (maybe 10 minutes or so). However, the live music was WAY too loud. I enjoy a band to liven up my dining experience as much as the next person, but it was so loud that we were not actually even able to talk to one another. We resorted to charades and miming in order to carry on our conversation, which was frustrating because we had met up with two friends that we hadn't seen in a while, and I had left my mime gear at home. We did complain to the waitress who seemed equally frustrated but unable to do anything about it. About 3/4 of the way through our experience we did get moved to another table and were finally able to chat, but by that point most of the evening was gone.

I didn't love the food, which was probably the biggest let down for me. I honestly expected to freak out based upon the ravings of my Emmett-fanboy coworker. However, when I have only eaten at a place a few times I feel that it is entirely possible that I just haven't found "my" dish there yet, so I'm definitely willing to give it another try and update my review when I do. But so far, I'm sitting at about a 2 star experience - I've definitely had better, both for weekend-out ambiance and for pub burgers and brews.

But on a positive note, I did get a pretty sweet Emmett tee-shirt!

Stopped in recently with a group for lunch after a meeting.  Great food and matching beer.  Happy to see a few vegetarian options on the menu.  Grabbed a six-pack and a bomber of the Imperial Stout to go.

Very happy, will be back again!

Award-winning beers (try the house porter/house munich pilsner). The beer cheese soup with pretzel bread stick is very satisfying. But the house fries aoili (truffle) MAY BE THE BEST FRIES IN CHICAGOLAND AREA. Service is sometimes hit-or-miss even when the place is not so busy;  humans get tired working in the service industry; I get it.

I had come here several years ago for dinner and remember not being impressed with the food, but loving the beer. Now I am older and more particular and while I'm not much of a beer drinker, I'm so happy I came back to try the food one more time.

I swung by here with my mom and hubs for lunch on Saturday and the place was nicely emptyish. I really liked that our server was still amazingly attentive even though we were one of maybe three tables he had. He was polite, courteous, paced our meal excellently, and didn't smother us. Hard to do, and done well!

The menu seems to be completely revamped! My eyes gravitated immediately to the fantastic small plates menu - specifically the bleu cheese and bacon potato chips. The menu said they were served with a horseradish dip that we sadly didn't get, but the chips were still deeeeelish and I coulda eaten a whole bowl of them. I'm glad we shared amongst the table. Then I ordered a crock of the baked french onion soup, which was awesome, and my mom got their cheddar ale soup, which I sampled and also loved! It wasn't just cloyingly cheesy, but had well developed flavors and didn't feel insanely heavy.

For lunch I really wanted to get a salad, but then I noted the pork belly tacos, and I'm a sucker for pork belly, so I ordered that. It wasn't my favorite - the other flavors on the taco were so strong I could barely tell there was pork belly on it - but it wasn't terrible. My husband got the sunrise burger and holy crrrrrrrap I wish I had gotten it - SO AMAZING and perfectly cooked and had BACON JAM on it. BACON JAM. What more do you need. 

After all that, my mom and I were stuffed but my husband pressed on and ordered the raspberry tiramisu, which looked completely beautiful and he adored.

The inside of the restaurant is warm, classy, and cozy, and the aforementioned service was outstanding. We'll definitely be back.

I hadn't been here since it was Founders Hill (or Founders-as I enter middle age hood, I tend to add words to titles) many years ago.  We went on a Sunday afternoon for lunch and there were mixed reviews within our group.

It's a nice, cozy place and the bar area is well set up with TV's, high tops and plenty of bar stools.   We didn't have any drinks, so will likely update this review down the road when I do.

Good service overall and the food items were either very good, or in some instances, subpar.   The ale cheese soup was a hit, as were the soft pretzels, which came with a honey mustard sauce and horseradish cheese spread.   My wife's Reuben, son's shrimp boursin pasta, and dad's rigatoni pasta were well liked, as were the homemade chips.

Two of us ordered tacos-my ahi tuna ones were o.k.-the fish was good, and I like that they offered corn or flour tortillas (always corn for me!) but overall, they were dry-recalled reading about a chipotle or similar flavored sauce, which wasn't there.  My mom's steak tacos were a disaster-there was almost no edible meat present.  The server and manager were understanding and handled the situation well.

Overall, pretty good place.  Next time I'll try some of their beer(s) and venture within the menu for food.

This is more of a review of the special events service of Emmett's vs. their retail operation.

Emmett's sent out a staff member (Chris A. from the corporate HQ) to come to our not-for-profit event several days ago. They served their pale ale and honey blonde ale, both of which were very popular with the attendees. Chris, a former bartender for Emmett's, was very knowledgeable about the products, and interacted with everyone in a friendly, accessible way.

When we have a similar event in the future, we will definitely consider Emmett's. Friendly staff and great brews - what more could you ask for?

We didn't plan anything for Valentines day & just took our daughter out to dinner with us. Reservations were made the same day without a problem. Parking in the area is a little tough & their lot in the back is a tight fit but we made it right on time.

We arrived & were greeted and seated right away. That's always a plus, right? Right. 

I noticed that the music and noise level from the bar side is something you cannot ignore while sitting down for dinner.. eh, I'm not sure how I feel about this..

Moving on... I ordered a cucumber gimlet for a pre-dinner drink (it's pretty much a gin martini) which was good. Not too strong & pretty much right on point. Yes, I know I was at a brewery BUT I had my eye set on the prime rib & knew there was no room in my stomach for both! 
Soooo . . . I ordered the prime rib dinner special - cooked medium, baked potato & split pea soup of the day. 
 
The split pea had good flavor but the chunks of ham were not what you're use to getting in split pea. I am pretty sure it was deli ham, which made me a little sad. Oh & there were no croutons in the soup... Really?! What a let down! 

I ordered a glass of the Sycamore Lane Cabernet Sauvignon & I think that was the best decision I had made about the meal.
When the prime rib came out, it was exceptionally pink & I mean near rare. I seriously tried to eat it but ended up sending it back .. I just couldn't do it. When it came back from the kitchen, it wasn't rare or medium or medium well for that matter, it was almost well done. Needless to say, I ate more towards them middle & set it to the side. 

This place is not terrible, but could use a little revamping... maybe I will give em another shot.. we'll see.

Went there for the first time on Thursday. The hawks/St. louis game was on and had a good time. The beers were great (I had a red ale and the porter) but in my opinion the music and TV we're a little too loud for my taste

This place has a nice atmosphere, but that doesn't make up for so-so food at ridiculous prices. We had the "all you can eat" fish and chips. The meal came with soup or salad. Salad was okay, nice mix of greens but the croutons were soggy and the salad was small. The Bleu cheese dressing was generic and tasteless. There were two pieces of fish on each plate. Not bad flavor but way too much batter. The cole slaw was not good - too much mayo. The waitress didn't offer more fish; my husband had to ask for another piece, thinking another batch might be better. The fries were good. 

We had water to drink and the bill was over $40. I doubt we'll be back to do anything but stop in at the bar. Disappointing.

Thursday night half-price pitchers are awesome, the beer is really good! They have more seasonal beers with the current brewer than they used to. And Tiffany the bartender is fun to talk to! She has a great energy. It's not a sports bar but they have lots of tv's spaced around the bar area. Emmett's is a great place to hang out!

Great outdoor patio and bar inside.  Cold beer is cold beer, but Service was mediocre.  DO NOT order the beef nachos.  2 days later my stomach still hurts. Beef was charred, tasteless. I've eaten here before and had much better food.

Emmett's has a nice location in Downtown DG and their atmosphere is pretty cool - then again, anything like taps, kegs, or stills are cool to me.  I personally think their food is better than the beer.  The food fare is normal American cuisine and they don't overcharge for the food in my opinion.  It is well prepared and presented and the staff if courteous and polite.  The beer is 'eh' in my opinion; I've had a lot better.  Some of the prices of their beers also cause me to not drink when I go here.

Seating is a non-issue with their bar and plenty of tables.  The girls at the front are always nice when it comes to hospitality.  

I would like to see an improvement in the beer prices.  I think they are a little on the high side for what they are worth.  Overall; a fine establishment but they need to add a little bit to take it to the next level.

Had the lettuce wrap for an appetizer and the chicken was great as well as the peanut sauce. I would recommend this to start as it is light but very taste. Had the baby back ribs and they fell off the bone and where fantastic. Had the cream of mushroom soup instead of the salad and was very pleased I chose that option.  Another great time at Emmett's.

For those of you have read my other reviews, you know I try to be fair and subjective regarding my reviews. I never give a bad review on a singular experience, that sort of thing.

This was our second time there, the first was somewhat forgettable so we thought we'd try it again. It was busy on a Friday night at about 8, but not crazy busy. We ordered drinks and food pretty quickly, and my first clue that our waitress was not very professional was when she wrote our food order on a cocktail napkin. No kidding-we waited 50 minutes for our dinners. Really? A salad and their all you can eat Fish Fry??? A couple of excuses from our waitress as table after table around us were seated, got their food, ate and left. Finally we asked for a manager and she said she would check on it real quick and after 5 or so minutes, out comes the food. The food wasn't bad but when it takes that long, really, who the heck cares?

The one that really got my husband is they seated a very large party near us so the chairs were right up against us, and the waitress at that table kept plowing into my husband with not word one of an apology. Inexcusable.

They tried to make it up by comping our meal, but we will NEVER return. EVER ever ever!!!!! It was exhausting being that upset over what should have been a nice date night...

Recent dinner experience was pretty lame. Tried a couple beers (German Altbier & Roggenbier) that were pretty lackluster. Watered down, hard to drink even. Dinner house salad was LAME. Thin shreds of carrots, two slices of tomato, cucumber, onions, a handful of croutons, all topped some pieces of iceberg lettuce. No doubt the most unexciting, boring house salad I've ever seen. The entree of BBQ Baby Back Ribs continued the mediocrity. Small ribs, very fatty, slathered in sauce completely erasing any flavor the pork may have had. I'm sure they picked them up at Costco or Restaurant Depot. I expected more than generic for $25. Definitely reminded me why I dislike boiled pork baby backs. The accompanied "loaded" baked potato was the SADDEST thing I've ever seen. Small, slightly cut down the middle, with only pinches of cheddar cheese and bacon bits attempting to grace the interior. I can honestly say, Emmett's served THE WORST baby back ribs, side salad, and loaded baked potato I've ever eaten. If the food and drink weren't sad enough, our waitress (although friendly) seemed as clueless as the chef. For working in a brewhouse, she couldn't describe their beers. For serving steak and prime rib, she couldn't tell the difference between rare, medium-rare, medium, or overdone. It was easy to see that Emmett's is NOT the place to go for food; it's overpriced crap (ala Chef Ramsey). I'd hasten to say it's not the place for beer either. In a time of gastropubs and independent, home-grown micro-breweries, this place falls to the wayside...next door to Applebee's and Chili's. WEAK!

I went here on a Saturday night around 9, to meet with friends for drinks. As I walked in, the hostess at the desk walked away... 'Soooo I'm thinking I should seat myself??' I thought. The place was starting to empty out. We chose a seat on the bar side- nice high top tables, a view of the brewing equipment, great music playing- and settled in. 

We waited. And waited.

I started to doubt the fact that we were supposed to seat ourselves. New to the place, I didn't know anything about the beers, and after 10 minutes, noticed an abandoned drink menu to look at. Finally a waiter appeared and got us waters. 

12 minutes later our friend arrived and the waiter appeared again and gave us helpful drink ideas. I had the 1am ale. It was decent, not super memorable though. It seemed like all of us had to work to finish our beers in the end. 

I was interested in trying one of their cocktails, but things ended up taking too long so we decided to take our business elsewhere. The beer prices were reasonable-- I think mine was 5.75 plus tax. 

I probably would try the place again, but it's not at the top of my list for the dg area.

Lots of brew pubs are offering "beer pairing dinners" now, but Emmett's in Downers Grove (formerly Founder's Hill Brewery) seems to have perfected them down to a science.

We signed up for Emmett's annual Spring Brewmaster Dinner on April 18, a five-course menu chosen by the chef (not available on the regular menu), served with different varieties of Emmett's brews specially chosen to complement each course. After an on-the-house beer and a tour of the small but busy brewery by Brewmaster Rob Hunter, we enjoyed:

* An appetizer of thin slices of pan-seared duck breast (nice and rare) served with orange-cranberry chutney and a tabbouleh patty of roasted tomato quinoa topped with black-peppered goat cheese, paired with Emmett's Belgian Abbey Ale. Nice balance of sweet and smoky flavors.

* A lobster and arugula salad with slivered jicama, served with a hoppy Citra IPA to complement the tartness of the lemon thyme dressing.

* For a palate-cleanser, a scoop of sorbet flavored with Apple Pucker schnapps, garnished with a slice of green apple and a drizzle of caramel (could have used A LOT more caramel!) 

* An entrÃ©e of rosemary roasted lamb chops in a basil pesto demi glace, served with candied baby carrots and purple potato puree garnished with a leaf of fried basil, paired with a hearty, malty Dopplebock. (This was my first taste of purple potatoes. Yum. Gotta find me some of those in my grocery store.)

* A Chocolate Bananas Foster dessert of caramelized bananas and chocolate ice cream garnished with mint leaves on top of a slice of vanilla pound cake, washed down with a chocolatey Java Stout. (This dessert was a little heavy on the chocolate and a little light on the bananas, but no complaints from me since I'm a chocolate lover.)

What I liked the most about this dinner, aside from the great cooking and beer choices, was that the portion sizes were just right. We left pleasantly satisfied, but not so overstuffed that we couldn't enjoy a few more after-dinner beers. The only thing keeping me from giving this dinner five stars was the price -- $60 per person. While this is not overly-expensive by any means, it's still $20 more than the beer pairing dinners we've had at Tribes Alehouse in Mokena, with the same number of courses and much bigger portion sizes.

Since we also signed up for Emmett's Beer Club, however, which gives us a 10% discount on future Brewmaster Dinners (along with free lunches on your birthday and a special Beer Club mug every time you visit), it's not a bad deal at all!

We go here 4-5 times a year and always have a good experience.  We are pretty laid back people that have both spent a very short time in serving so we know what it takes and what servers go through on a daily basis.  We are normally out for the night and never in a hurry.  That being said, we have not had slow service and the food is always been very good.  When things are busy we normally order a beer and tell the server to come back when they get a minute.  Good beer and good conversation makes time fly.  The beer selection is always changing as well as having their usual standard choices.  My wife and I had our rehearsal dinner there 8 years ago in their private room and that was also a well run evening.

We love Emmetts and always take advantage of their gift card promotion around the holidays for getting bonus money when purchased.

I haven't been to Emmett's in some time due to a less than stellar dining experience.  Last Saturday, I met a couple of girlfriends for drinks.  We arrived around 4pm and had no problem finding a seat in the bar area.  We stayed for a couple hours before moving on.  The bar area filled up pretty quickly but service was consistent throughout.  We had a few of their beers and shared a flight.  I ordered a couple items off of their small plates menu and was satisfied.  Nothing to complain about, a very solid drinking/dining experience.

We hadn't been to Emmett's in a while, but friends of ours dine here somewhat regularly.  I had the special of the day, pork chops with pineapple.  The pork chops were very good, nicely seasoned and cooked well.  The pineapple was grilled, but I could tell that it was freshly sliced and not out of a can.  The green beans were cooked nicely, not at all mushy.

I had the steak and black bean chili, which was flavorful, but not spicy hot.

My only complaint is that service was a bit slow.  Our server was very attentive, so I'm thinking that the slow pace wasn't her fault, but rather the kitchen being a little slow, since all of the food was hot, when it arrived at the table.  Certainly, I was able to enjoy the dinner conversation, but it just seemed that it took a little long for our soups/salads and entrees to arrive.

I do plan to include Emmett's in our regular rotation of restaurants.

We went out with a friend last night and wanted to try something new... Emmett's was right down the street from the game store that we love, so why not?!

We started with the Emmett's Baked Pretzel Twists Horseradish Cheese Spread, Pale Ale Mustard for $8.99 and a couple cups of Cheddar Ale Soup w/ a Pretzel Twist for $3.50.  On their own their both great and together they're even better!  Very good starters!

Our friend ordered the Brewer's Chicken Sandwich w/ Swiss, Bacon, Pale Ale Mustard on a Toasted Pretzel Roll & a side of Sweet Potato Fries for $9.99. She said it was a great tasting sammich and she schmeared on some of the mustard from the pretzels.  She also enjoyed the fries!  It was a pretty thick sammich which is a good deal for the price!

The boy ordered the Brewhouse Angus Burger 8oz burger, Brioche Bun for $9.99.  He asked for bacon on his burger and a side of their Truffle Fries.  This was an additional $2.25; however, for the price of the burger I think it was worth it.  The boy said that this was one of the better burgers he's had as it was well seasoned and very well cooked to his medium rare preference!

I ordered the all you can eat Beer Battered Cod w/ French Fries & Emmett's Slaw $16.99.  What a perfect Friday night special!  It was a serious toss up between this and the Prime Rib, but for the extra order to take home I was all for the fish fry!  It was a little on the oily side.  However, the flavor was spot on and it was a good flavor!  

Our server, Dave, was great!  He had a really good sense of humor and kept up with his tables even when the bar got bomb all at once!  I would totally recommend that anyone hit this place up for a good night!
Tavern Tacos are great!  Sat at the bar- staff was very accommodating and friendly.  Great place!

I consider Emmets a step above any chain restaurant. Really good food, love the small plate menu and great beer selection. Yesterday while ordering our food we were informed of a .50 charge for a side of bbq sauce. We spent $50 and they couldn't throw in a tablespoon of bbq sauce without a charge? Most chains and even fast food restaurants don't charge for this. It was a little tacky in my opinion.

Really - I was surprised! Maybe it's because of the craft breweries that populate California or the fact that Downers Grove has never been on my radar... regardless. Get yourself there and enjoy a great blend of fabulous beers and honest-to-goodness food that complements the beer. Is it worth 45 minutes of driving and IL toll roads? If you're looking for something new in the way of a quality brew-pub experience and don't want to deal with Chicago - the answer is an unequivocally, yes!

I am lucky that I have friends that live in DG and they both love to go to lunch here.  It's a great place because you have space and good acoustics to really chat and catch up.

They also have a wonderful patio here and summer is so short, it's a shame to waste it eating indoors!

I've had great burgers, salads and sandwiches here plus you have the option of sweet potato fries, sweet!  On my last visit I had a special sandwich, Chicken Bruschetta, that was delicious.  Their iced tea is also perfect, brisk and fresh.  Paired with anything it makes for a refreshing summer lunch.

Meeting a gal pal for lunch?  I'd head here immediately.  In fact, I'll come with you!

I wish I could go there more often! Their food is absolutely delicious! I have a wonderful experience every time I go! The staff is friendly and the food is exceptional! Good location just make sure to save a little extra time to find parking.

My first experience at Emmett's was shockingly bad. I went on a Thursday night for dinner. The restaurant was decently busy, but there were seats open at the bar and that's where I sat. 

I ordered the blackened steak sandwich with truffle fries and one of the seasonal beers (Belgian Stout). The sandwich was downright awful. If there was any blackening seasoning, I could not taste it and the steak itself was borderline inedible. It was probably a 8oz cut and I would estimate that 3oz were fat and gristle. I could not bite through the sandwich and had to resort to eating it with a knife and fork and even then I had trouble cutting the "steak". The beer was okay at best, not much going on with it. 

I would have sent the sandwich back and ordered something else, but I could not find the bartender or a server to talk to, with was a theme of the experience. Out of my time there I interacted with the bartender 3 times: 1) to order my food and beer 2) when my food arrived and 3) 10 min after I finished my beer and food and requested the check. Not once after I received my food did anyone check on me to see how everything was. 

I would give the experience 0 stars if I could, because that is truly what Emmett's deserves. Absolutely abysmal experience, I will probably not be returning.

Went out for dinner on a weds evening.  The place was busy but not packed.  The food is so so in quality especially for the prices.  My husband ordered a large plate of beef nachos.  For a pub they should be embarrassed.  A generous pile of non cooked chips, with a scant amount of some type of liquid cheese substance , a scant dab of guacamole, and a few scattered bits of tomato and a scant amount of ground beef.  Definitely overpriced, and really not appetizing in any definition of nachos.  I ordered the walleye bites, they were good, tasty , generous portion for an appetizer not badly priced.  we also ordered a bowl of french onion soup, the portion was not a bowl size it was more a cup size, watery, fair tasting, overpriced.   We also had a cup of chili, average tasting, but not bad as an appetizer.   My 3 year old grandson ordered mac and cheese, and it literally states on the menu "kraft" macaroni and cheese, it was $6, very overpriced.   I had a pub burger, was tasty but a little undercooked, on a nice bun, minimal toppings:  a slice of tomato, onion and a piece of lettuce, $10.  We both drank water only since they only serve pepsi products other than the beer.  Total bill was almost $60. Our waitress was not friendly or even polite.  She did come and refill my husbands half empty water glass, but not my completely empty water glass.   For the money have had much better food and much better service. Not recommending.

Like most Illinoisans, especially during the Stanley Cup Playoffs, I cheered the Hawks on!  However, instead of going to a crazy, jam packed bar with douchy dudes (yeah, you know  what I'm talking about), I went to Emmett's, a classier, full-spirited (both in liquor and atmosphere) watering hole!  I enjoyed watching a few of the Playoffs games without feeling like I was in a sardine can. 

But hockey hysteria aside, Emmett's is a great bar and restaurant.  They brew some good beer and their food is quite tasty.  I can recommend their truffle fries, pretzels, quesadillas, and burgers.  I wouldn't say its gastropub food nor dive bar food.... I would say, it sits pretty above the bell curve as upgraded bar food you wouldn't mind going back for.

Overall, its a decent local bar if you're ever in the DG area!

Stopped in for a quick lunch on a Monday. Sat a the bar a few minutes before anyone said hi. Bartender was unfriendly when I asked for recommendations. Maybe a case of the Mondays? She brought me my food and seemed to busy with her friends at the other end of the bar to ask how everything was. (She actually just checked in ) a little late but you can when someone doesn't want to be at work. Wings were good and the beer was decent. Probably won't be back.

Yet another restaurant that I can't explain why we didn't visit sooner. 

We'd been to the Emmett's in West Dundee. We liked it. So I'm not sure why we took so long to come here. Emmett's is sleek, a classy brewpub even in the bar area where we sat. Although they brew their own beer, I had to go for the Lapinette, a local cider I'd wanted to try. It was delicious. 

We started with nachos, which were very good with crispy chips, cheddar beer sauce and pico plus a solid lime-y guac. My compadres ordered a burger and a chicken sandwich and I had fish tacos. I liked that I was able to get one with fried cod and one with grilled ahi. I was offered my choice of side and had house-made potato chips.

My tacos were delicious and messy. The ahi was a little dry on its own but the toppings saved it. The cod was nice and crispy. The chips were good, solid though not exceptional.

Service was very good, prompt with refills and plenty of checking in, but not overbearing. 

This seems like a great place for a beer and a burger or a classy night out with a date or the fam. Glad to add it to the list of options.

This is our favorite place for food and drinks in Downers Grove. The portobello sand which is my favorite. I get it almost every time. The truffle fries are really good but if you are getting an app then j would go with emmett's baked pretzel twists.

This is a good place for better than average pub food.  Service is often not great.  Watch out for takeout orders.  I received my order nicely packaged up but when I go home, found that the order was wrong.  That type of experience is disappointing. That's why 3 stars instead of 4.

McCarthy Red Ale is probably their best ale. They have a very under rated burger that is a must try. There is plenty of beer choice but for the most part aside from the red the other ales are avg at best. Now I am a beer snob so take my input as you may :) Take advantage of late night bar eats because you do get a variety of delicious options. Overall I give this place 3 stars because for a beer establishment the beer should be better. Service could be better. This place has a lot more potential if owners just focused more on their beer development.

Great place for large groups and parties.  We held my Dad's memorial here yesterday and everything went smoothly.  Met with Kirsten before the event to discuss details and throughout the process, she was organized, friendly and super helpful.  

We opted for the 2entree lunch buffet in their event room.  The beef and pork entrees, vegetable primavera and roasted potatoes were delicious.  They have a projector and microphone.  Highly recommend.

We went here on a Saturday night. The service was quick, though the servers seemed a little confused. Just a little confused as to who was bringing the food and who was picking up the check. It wasn't always our waitress. Sometimes it was another. And after we paid, our waitress asked if we had paid or not and who took our check. 
The bar area was pretty busy, so we ate in the dining room. We were seated at a gigantic booth. The two of us. It looked like it would be big enough for 4-6 people in reality.
Anyway, the food was good. I had tuna tacos & Fred had a chicken & bacon sandwich. They were good, but not our favorite. The tuna seemed like it was a little overdone.
So pretzels are trendy and we had them. Meh.
It seems like 75% of places that have pretzel sticks all use the same pretzel stick company. Same shape, some color, same taste. Going from restaurant to restaurant it seems as though it just depends on how long they were frozen and how long the frozen sticks were in the oven. Some places don't use frozen pretzels. This place does. It comes with a sweet mustard which was tasty and also a "horseradish cheese spread". The cheese spread was very horseradish-y and it would've required a knife to spread it on the pretzel. Not optimal for dipping.

Overall, not my favorite. So many places in the area, I don't know if I'd go back.

The beer and food are great, but the service leaves tons to be desired. The place has lots of potential, but it just isn't reaching it. 3 of us adults went for dinner on a Sunday evening (it wasn't very crowded) and dinner took 2.5 hours. We all order soup or salad, which took about 25 minutes for one of us to get our French Onion soup. We then placed our order and one person ordered fish, the others order a chicken dish and a burger. After about 30 minutes (after we got our soup/salad) the waitress came out to tell us that our food was coming soon but they forgot to cook the fish. We finally got our mean about 10-15 minutes later but the burger and chicken dish were cold because they clearly had been cooked a long time ago and sat in the kitchen while they made the fish. The restaurant did a good job and offered us a complimentary dessert. We ordered a slice of carrot cake (huge slice) to split. The cake took about 20 minutes to bring out. Two people ordered coffee, and the de-caff coffee they were freshly brewing took another 20-25 minutes. 

In the end, the food was good (although much of it was cold) and the craft beers were also great. But the service made us question if it is worth going back. We were actually there testing the food to decide if we should hold a rehearsal dinner in their banquet space, but after the experience we had, we quickly took our business to another restaurant down the street.

Save your money; go across the street to Ballydoyle for an Irish boxty.  I rarely write bad reviews, because I prefer to promote good places, not be snippy about so-so ones, but this was an outstanding exception.

Went to Downers Grove location for a special night out with my friend, and decided to try Emmett's because from the outside it looks a little fancier than Ballydoyle. The martini and potato were good. That is all. Horribly rude and oblivious wait staff.   We had three waiters blatantly ignore us for a good 10 minutes, and we finally flagged a staff person down, it took them another 10 minutes to find "our" waitress instead of asking if he could start us with drinks and then track her down!  Really??  Our waitress was unapologetic, rarely came to the table, and the smallish bar was only half full with a staff of FIVE!  I tried not to be the "witchy" patron, used my pleases and thank yous, but even my friend was like, "It's like she's purposely ignoring us."

My martini and water were empty, so I had nothing to drink with my meal and I didn't want my expensive dinner to go cold.  I flagged her down to get water, since a different server brought us our food, and didn't ask us if we needed anything.  I waited, and waited.  I had to walk up to the Idle bartender (no one up there ordering drinks at that time) and immediately refilled my water.   After serving two other tables water, she came by and said, "Oh, someone got your water?"  By this point I got snippy and said, "I went up to the bar and got it myself."  She said a flat toned sorry, shrugged her shoulders, and said, "Want a martini?" She ignored my friend, didn't ask us if there's anything else she could get us, just wanted me to buy another high priced martini after being treated like subhuman the whole dinner.

I got a "queen" prime rib, thinking I'd treat myself.  It tasted like tough rump roast from a crock pot.  Prime rib is supposed to be cooked in seasoned juices, really tender, and this was gross and bland.  It's the Friday and Saturday special, so maybe it was dried out leftovers?  I only ate about 5 bites, and I felt sick later!  When we waved the waitress down for our check, instead of noticing I pretty much left a $20 prime rib on the plate, she asked, disinterested, "want me to box that?". We even put our credit cards on the table at the end, to get out faster, and our waitress plopped the bill on the table and walked away, not even noticing our credit cards were sitting right beside the bill.   Won't be back, ever, thanks.  We should have eaten across the street at Ballydoyle where the food is reasonably priced, staff is friendly, and ambience is less pretentious.
Went to the new one on Front St. in Wheaton.  Nice atmosphere.  Beer was good.  Food was good, but kind of pricey for a burger.  Nice variety of menu items.   Overall very satisfied and will return

Two words: FISH TACOS!  The tuna steak used on the tacos is not only fresh, it's expertly prepared (cooked a bit more than seared, yet perfectly pink inside).  This place is a Pescetarian's delight!!   The only thing I would change is the white sauce on the tacos - I prefer a red, more salsa type.  But hey, to each his own.  

Also getting high marks are  the seafood appetizers (walleye bites & seafood platter) - both exceed expectations for a brew pub.   

The one item on the menu that disappoints, the Mac & Cheese entree - for a brew pub this should be much better.   Oh well, stick to the seafood and you won't go wrong here.

I am going to do my best to point out both the good and bad. 

Let me start with the good, because I don't want to forget the good points. They have a parking lot out back in case you can not find street parking on Main. Their restrooms are pretty nicely maintained. And the overall interior of the bar/restaurant is clean and very comfortable. The hard wood and dark tile make this place very relaxing and probably a good after work hang out for the locals. 

Now, sadly, I have to let you know the crappy stuff. When we got here, I went right to the washroom. My fiance and his sister grabbed a high top table in the center of the bar area and planted themselves so we had a place to sit.

When I returned from the restroom, my fiance's sister had a beer in front of her and my fiance had a mixed drink in front of him with a bill sitting next to it. I asked, "why is there a bill? Can I order a drink?"  At no fault of ours, the extremely unpleasant cocktail server dropped the bill with his drink, did not ask if we wanted to run a tab or if anyone else may want to order a drink that is joining them. Right when I sat down at the table, this woman walked up to my fiance, lifted up the bill for his drink and slapped it back down on the table and said, and I quote: "we can close that out now." WTF?!? Hello??? Do you not see me? Am I invisible?? 

Well, let me tell you. I ordered from the bar. Ran a tab with them and let them earn my tip. I was appalled by her behavior. Could not believe that she treated this in such a manner. My fiance, who rarely complains about anything, even was shocked. 

In no hurry to return.

You'll get a deja vu feeling after walking through the door...I mean I've been here before like a thousand time in a thousand different cities.  Now that's not a bad thing it just is.......nothing wrong with this place, nothing right either i guess.  I'm in a pissy mood but I could have easily given them four stars.  Not a reason to go to Downers but really there are no reasons to go to Downers.

This location of Emmetts, was just disappointing.  

The inside areas are large and inviting. Bar room might be a little bit dark. Who cares really? Outside is a small area with only a handful of tables.

It was a warm evening, so we opted to sit outside!  Service was adequate. We received our drinks in a timely manner.
The food order, was another discussion. First of all, we both ordered off the gluten-free menu. My friend ordered a salad and expected the croutons. She was disappointed when there were no croutons. Our server told us that you don't have gluten-free croutons. So why were croutons listed on the menu? Okay, now let's discuss my Rehberger. Have you ever tasted the gluten-free buns you're using? They are terrible!  Eating gluten-free, doesn't mean I'm desperate to eat anything! They were tasteless dry etc. etc.

Now for the meat,  if you're asked how you want your meat cooked. It would be nice if you got sort of close to the temperature you requested. I ordered my burger RAW, so that may be came medium rare. No such luck! It came well done. Very disappointing! I can't eat well done meat. So I sent it back! I thought that maybe I come back better?? Well this time it came back medium. ALL I can say is I was disappointed. I expected better from your restaurant

I have been to Emmetts many times and felt I finally must say how good they are, not only the food but the service.  We have been there a few times with ten plus people and only one server, today we had sixteen with one server and she did an amazing job!

The food is well priced and delicious, love their fish tacos.  I feel they are a hidden gem in the western suburbs.

Went here for an office holiday lunch.  I think the biggest problem is the parking situation, but it is in downtown Downers Grove, so it's probably an issue at any nearby business.  They did let us park in the church though and street parking seemed ample (4 hr limit).
The food was good.  I believe they brew their own beer, which is always a cool thing.  They had a nice selection of fish chicken and beef.  Their sides were also delicious.  I would definitely go here for a meal sometime based on this.

I am a huge fan of wings (and brew pubs). I went here with a friend after work and got a very good heavy stout. While there, I learned that they had a $0.50 wing night on Wednesday. Given my positive initial experience, I had to come back.

We decided to come back to watch the NHL playoffs. The atmosphere was great: lots of TV's, friendly staff, and great food. On Wednesday, they have $0.50 wings as long as you buy a drink and buy 12 wings. They have daily $4 specials of their freshly brew that varies by the day. I got a McCarthy Red, which was fantastic and went well with the wings.

The wings (see photo) were as big as I've gotten and they were very meaty. There was just enough sauce and the sauces were great: I got bourbon, a peanut sauce (I think), and hot sauce. Since I went with my buddies, I traded to get their BBQ sauce too, which was equally impressive. These are some of the best wings I've had, which is saying a lot. $0.50 a piece is a great deal (although, you have to buy a drink).

The atmosphere was lovely. Lots of great TVs playing all sorts of games. During the course of the evening, we saw the Heat Boston game, our hockey game, the US vs Brazil soccer match, and the Sox and Cubs games. The atmosphere had some kids and many older adults, which allowed us to enjoy the game. All of us had a great time: great beer, great food, nice atmosphere. We will definitely be back!

just a note - that the Brewing Company AND the Ale House are listed by Yelp as separate businesses.

This is being posted to the Emmett's Brewing Co.

I love the Emmett's in Dundee. have never had a problem there. the downers grove location is a different matter. two of us were there for an early dinner on Monday, and the place was deserted. we both ordered burgers. pretty simple. both orders came out wrong. the server was mia most of the time, we waited a looooooooooong time for those dirty plates to go away. I was charged two dollars too much for a side salad. really poor service, good enough food.

I convinced my husband to give Emmett's another try.  We sat at the bar when we first got there. The bartender was less than interested and seemed very bored.  I'm not a big beer drinker, so ordered a glass of wine.  Neither the Chardonnay or Pinot Grigio were all that great.

We moved to a table when friends joined us.  The waitress was friendly and fairly attentive.  The Walleye appetizer was very good - however - we got 4 small pieces for $11.99.  Way to pricey.  The burger and turkey burger were both tasty, but again way over priced.  Hard to believe there's a $.75 charge for grilled onions. 

I hate leaving a restaurant really feeling like we've wasted our money.  Sadly, this was the case.  I doubt we go back. Too many other alternatives in the area.

I went there last night for a late dinner, and was very happy. I got a dark beer, Poor Richards I believe, right up my alley, and a burger with pears on it. Surprisingly good. And their sweet potato fries were great too.
The waitress was super friendly and the service fast. All in all, most satisfying.

Wait staff was prompt and "Small Plates" were delightfully tasty. We had the Walleye Bites and Tavern Tacos (cod) along with a beer flight. I recommend these items confidently. As the evening lengthened (we participated in a Wine and Canvas event), the temperature increased and the service declined (one server for a group of 25-30 people) though she tried to keep up. Being an Ale House, I suppose I shouldn't have ordered a Patron Margarita (though it WAS on the drink special list). It was awful (premix maybe?) And unsalted. At the end of the evening I even had to go in search of the server to get my card back.

I should preface this with my game group plays here every week.  In the past I would have reviewed this as a 3 because the menu was just not overly interesting and their wait staff can be hit or miss.  

The new menu on the other hand is a great improvement.  Small plates, which aren't trying to be tapas, but just smaller servings of their normal meals at a reduced price are great.  I always felt the tendency to overeat there because I couldn't find what I wanted at the size I wanted.  Now instead of ordering appetizer of giant pretzel sticks you can get one with a soup or to add to a salad.  The small plate sandwiches are good too because they come with a small version of the fries too.  The dessert menu has also been changed around.  They still seem to be mostly huge desserts so if you don't want to leave feeling like you've eaten your weeks' worth of calories in one day, share it.  :-)

They are pretty accommodating and pretty forgiving about our game group if we have a bigger group than they expect and spread out a little further into the room due to the wall table being occupied.  

I can't touch on the beers but as far as ciders go there isn't too much of a selection.  Just Strongbow in bottles all the time and an occassional one on tap.

I drive past this place everyday, but I rarely eat here. That's partly because there are so many places like this in the area, and because the food isn't really anything special. I do like the dining room, bar area and outdoor patio, and every time I have been here it has been very clean, which is a huge plus.

On our most recent visit, our party of five was seated quickly and all the staff, from the hostess to our waitress to the food runners, was extremely friendly. Our waitress aptly described the homemade beer selections and outline the drink specials of the day.

I tried samples of a couple of the house beers; they were OK. A red ale had a bitter finish, but the pilsner I ended up ordering was better. I know they're trying to sell their own beer, but I'd like a larger selection of non-Emmett's beers on the menu just to balance things out.

A member of our group ordered the garlic and white truffle fries appetizer, and they were awesome -- crisp and flavorful without the garlic being overwhelming. I would definitely order these in the future.

My entree was the Firestarter Burger. Maybe it's because I've obliterated my taste buds with spicy food over the years, but I didn't find this spicy at all, despite the roasted jalapenos and Sriracha mayo. Roasting the peppers took some of the bite off, and they really skimped on the mayo. The burger itself was decent, but not the kind that would keep you coming back. That being said, I was in the mood for a smaller meal I could finish in one sitting; the chicken sausage pasta, fish and chips, and sherried chicken breast were other dishes I was considering before settling on a burger that I knew I could finish at this meal.

Emmett's might be getting pressure from Ballydoyle and Another Round across the street, but their menu is a little more diverse. Ballydoyle is basically Irish pub food and Another Round is basically American Pub food (with amazing pizzas). Emmett's is a pub, but their menu is a bit more grown up, i.e. it's not all just dumped into a fryer and served to you a minute later. In that sense, Emmett's certainly has its niche and their service is better than the other two places put  together.

I don't spend much time in Downers Grove. Actually, I don't spend any time there, this was my first time. Hubs had a business lunch at Emmett's and left his corporate card behind (oops!) so I went with him to pick it up. After what felt like a day-long road trip, we stayed for dinner. It's a nice place, although I was surprised to find the bar virtually empty at almost 7:00 pm. Do Downers Grovers not eat out on Wednesdays? The dining room was even more of a ghost town.

They have a nice beer selection, a few in-house brews as well as guest breweries. I had their 1 AM Ale; hoppy and a little sweet, and quite good. We split the blue crab stuffed mushrooms, which were really good. I hadn't expected to like them, because mushroom apps always seem to be overwhelmingly mushroom-y. These were not, and all of the flavors were distinctive. I had the Kobe burger, and hubs had the fish & chips, both with the homemade chips. My burger was perfectly cooked, very tasty, and the homemade chips were really good. Our waiter has a hoot, the service was great, and they even had the White Sox game on. Only 3 stars, you say? If I lived closer it would be a great place to hang, but, I don't imagine I'll be hauling out to DG with any regularity. I hope they get more action on weekends.

I met my new manager here for lunch and my nostrils were assaulted by the "hoppy" smell upon entering. I understand that they have their own brewery here but I don't remember Goose Island ever having such a pungent odor.
I had the French dip sammich with sweet potato fries - the fries were delicious but the beef was pretty dry and the au jus was wayyy too salty.
I will definitely come back here though and try some of the other signature dishes on the menu because I think I just ordered the wrong thing and I would love to try some of their house beers as well.

My riding crew was distressed to find that Two Brothers was closed for the day - after we had ridden all the way there. Thinking quickly, I remembered there was a brewpub in my parents' town. While still suburban in look and feel (too big, too shiny), Emmett's offered a delicious stout that rivaled Guinness, a refreshing IPA and other tasty beers.

Food options are limited for vegans. I got the truffle fries; they said the aioli was on the side but forgot to mention there was flakes of cheese on top. Thankfully it wasn't melted in so I picked it out and gave it to my non-vegan friend. Unfortunately I think a lot of the truffle oil went with the cheese, but there were still several addicting bites.

Good thing we had stopped here - it started pouring rain soon after we sat down, then let up before we left. Perfect timing!
I love coming here when visiting my son. The food is good and the beer is great...its cozy, friendly, and consistent.

In my quest to find the perfect beer friends suggested that Emmett's be a must-see (or in my case, a must drink) in the suburbs.  I've been here a couple of times now (only in the bar area) and it has always been the same.  Pretty good beer, pretty good food, and pretty bad service.  First off, let's talk about the beers:  I have tried the Victory IPA (which is also sold in bottles at Binny's in Bloomingdale! Yahoo!) and it is really good.  I like super hopped up beers, so I wish it was even hoppier, but it'll do.  It has a good, strong malty backbone so the hops don't seem that bad.  Good bitterness overall.
